awd_titl_txt: Marine Geological Samples Laboratory:  Graduate School of Oceanography, University of Rhode Island(support of marine sample curation)
awd_abstract_narration: Samples of seafloor rocks, cores, corals, hydrothermal vent fluids and chimney deposits, sediments, other materials are valuable scientific resources that are collected at great expense on scientific oceanographic expeditions.  Some samples come from shallow, near-shore environments of unusual and ephemeral character and others come from mid-ocean ridges, seamounts, the abyssal plain, the roots of volcanic islands, and continental shelves.  Many samples come from inaccessible places miles below the surface of the ocean and are retrieved from the seafloor by specialized robotic vehicles, human occupied submersibles, coring devices, and/or rock dredges.  To preserve these valuable samples and make them available to other scientists for studies not envisioned by the original collectors, the Marine Geology and Geophysics Program of the Division of Ocean Sciences of the National Science Foundation funds four professionally run repositories that house samples collected by seagoing scientists.  This award funds the curation, storage, and distribution of marine seafloor samples by the University of Rhode Island's Marine Geological Sample Laboratory. Samples are distributed upon request to scientists and educators wishing to better understand the ocean basins, the distribution of its resources, and how the Earth works. Over the past 3 years, this repository has distributed more than 8,000 samples of seafloor material to US and international scientists to advance our knowledge of the seafloor, ocean crust, mantle, seafloor volcanism, and the history of ocean chemistry and Earth's climate.  Samples from the repositories have been used to pioneer new analytical techniques and provide important insights into seafloor, the continental margins, and sub-oceanic magmatic processes.  This award augments a significant investment by the University of Rhode Island by supporting additional staffing in the form of a graduate student dedicated to working with the other repository staff to maintain the collection, collect and verify submitted information on the samples, and enter these data and metadata into an online database that makes the collection visible to interested parties via the Internet so scientists and educators can find and request samples for research and education.  Broader impacts of the work include graduate level course involvement and public outreach via tours for primary and secondary school groups, local community organizations, and other interested parties.  This award also provides support for an essential piece of marine geology infrastructure and provides support to an institution in a state that does not receive a significant amount of Federal funding (i.e., an EPSCoR state).

por.por_cntn:
The Marine Geological Samples Laboratory (MGSL) at the Graduate School of Oceanography, University of Rhode Island is an open-access repository for marine rock and sediment samples. We archive one of the world?s most extensive collections of geological samples from the deep ocean basins. Our collection contains more than 15,000 specimens of lava from underwater volcanoes, chimneys from hydrothermal vents, and sediment from every major ocean basin. In addition to the physical samples themselves, we maintain a database of information about each sample, including the place of collection, size, general description, and photographs.
For the past 35 years, our facility has served as a kind of library for these samples, taking in new collections from ship-based expeditions that sample the seafloor, archiving them and making their data publicly available through services like the NOAA IMLGS, and loaning them out to researchers, educators, and museums for scientific work and public education. Our services provide an essential return on the investments made by the National Science Foundation in the expensive work of seagoing marine geological science, offering continued availability of samples at a vastly reduced cost compared to the expense of re-collecting samples from an important location. The value of our collections also grows with every new study and discovery.
Over the term of this funding period (2016-2022), we archived new samples from the Southern Ocean, the Puerto Rico Trench, the remote western Aleutian Islands, unexplored seafloor regions of US territory in the western Pacific, and many others. We filled requests to distribute more than 3,000 samples to global researchers, educators, and museums, and led facility tours and outreach efforts that reached over 11,000 people.
The MGSL facility is run by a team of faculty, graduate students, and URI undergraduates. The tasks of the laboratory provide the student employees with opportunities to develop critical skills in hands-on geological science, GIS, and data/collections management. MGSL is also a teaching laboratory that supports upper level undergraduate and graduate education at URI through the use of facility space and physical collections to support educational exercises in courses like OCG440/540: Geological Oceanography. In 2020-2021, the MGSL supported the development of 50 take-home laboratory kits for students in this class when URI policies mandated virtual teaching under COVID-19 restrictions. These lab kits provided a way for students to have hands-on learning experiences even in a remote learning environment. The kits remain a valuable teaching resource for our curriculum.

 


Last Modified: 10/21/2022
Modified by: Katherine A Kelley
